nodes.bodyText: What's the purpose of this change?

This is good question, so when I do gradle test, this test class failed because it uses the RecordTemplatePlaceholder and it is not a real template,  on the other hand, in my newly added code, i need to have a fully function resource model instance.
routingResult.getResourceMethod().getResourceModel().getValueClass();

If we keep using the RecordTemplatePlaceholder, we will get an exception.
The ResourceModel takes an RecordTemplate as the input, the change from  RecordTemplatePlaceholder  to use resourceSchema seems to be a perfect fit. It is needed to say, I don't know why the original code uses the RecordTemplatePlaceholder rather than the real resourceSchema

I don't think this is a good idea. Using a random record type like ResourceSchema is misleading and made me believe that this logic is inherently related to resource schemas. I'd suggest you do one of two things:

Be explicit about using a dummy record by using something like EmptyRecord.
Fix the issue in RecordTemplatePlaceholder, this is an easy fix, since you can just define the schema as new RecordDataSchema(new Name(RecordTemplatePlaceholder.class.getCanonicalName()), RecordDataSchema.RecordType.RECORD).
I removed the change, it looks like I no longer need this change anymore. Will notice your suggestion next time when same situation happen
Move to com.linkedin.restli.internal.server.response to be aligned with the location of ResponseUtils

I think you can simplify the logic by reversing the checks.
First check and compute the field value:
if( dataDefaultFilled.containsKey())
   Object fieldData = // get data from datamap
else if field has default
  fieldData = // get field default.
else
  // continue (nothing to do).

Then compute the default for the field by calling recursively:
if fieldData instaceOf DataMap || instance of DataList
  fieldData = fillInDefaults(fieldData, fieldSchema)

dataDefaultFilled.put(fieldName, fieldData)

I'm don't think this would work for batch, finder or action methods. Can you add test coverage for these?
Check the restli validator on response method to understand different response structures. I feel it might be easier to add the fill default logic in ResponseBuilders

I saw there is a RestLiValidationFilter which implements Filter interface, it has a onResponse function,
also there are multiple **ResponseBuilders where they all share same interface RestLiResponseBuilder
I don't know how to fit the fill-default in there yet, will dig deeper.
I'd suggest renaming this to be consistent with the terminology used elsewhere in this PR. String FILL_DEFAULTS_PARAM = "$fillDefaults"; or String FILL_IN_DEFAULTS_PARAM = "$fillInDefaults"
This is a mouthful. I'd suggest renaming to isFillDefaultsRequested or isFillInDefaultsRequested

\ No newline at end of file
+
+  /**
+   * This is to determine whether the service will fill in default values when the returned value record has some missing
+   * field. In case:
+   * 1. the client is requesting that the default value to be returned. Reads the appropriate
+   * query parameter to determine this information, defaults to false if the query parameter isn't present.
+   * 2. the server is configured to return default value for every request-response pair
+   * @return true if the service need to fill in default value when the field of the return value record is absent
+   */
+  boolean isDefaultValueFillInRequested();

nodes.bodyText: Suggest changing the param to $fillInDefaults to be consistent
Yeah, will also need to change design doc

Though this finder is used only for testing, I prefer the methods to follow convention.
totalCount shouldn't be a query parameter, you should use the paging context "count" param for this. https://linkedin.github.io/rest.li/user_guide/restli_server#finder
You can add a query parameter for a field, eg noDefaultFieldA and return dummy records with that field filled in to match the query param.
Also rename the finder method to noDefaultFieldA to follow convention
nit: remove the extra comma

I suggest you test both scenarios: with fillInDefaults flag and without it.
You don't have to do it for all methods, just doing that for GET should be enough. For other methods, test only with fillInDefaults flag.
remove
Change to a log message (debug/info)
This section should be refactored to avoid duplication with the else block
Avoid duplication
When you fail to create the value instance, you should return 500 error, not fall back to value without default.
Initialize with size computed using DataMapBuilder::getOptimumHashMapCapacityFromSize

+  /**
+   * Used to fill in the default field for a data record if the record is having the field but not "complete"
+   * Basically, a simplified psuedo code is:
+   *  FillInDefault(schema, dataMap):

+   *     if fieldSchema instanceOf RecordDataTemplate:

+   *       else:

+   *           FillInDefault(fieldSchema, newData)
+   *       data.put(field, newData)
+   *     else if fieldSchema instanceOf TypeRefDataTemplate:
+   *       FillIndFefault(schema.deReference(), data)
+   *     else:
+   *       if !data.contains(field) && field.hasDefaultValue():
+   *         data.put(field, field.getDefaultValue())
+   * @param dataSchema -> a schema of the corresponding dataMap
+   * @param dataMap -> a dataMap that needs to be filling the default
+   * @return a new different data map that contains original data plus the default values
+   */

nodes.bodyText:
For fields of array, in the code I assume the following case:
Case 1 When the schema provide default
testFieldArray: array[MidLevelRecordWithDefault] = [{"intWithDefault": 0, "intWithoutDefault": 0}]

Case 2 When schema does not have default
In case 1, I will just use the default provided.
In case 2, there will be no defaults filled in.
I think this is an important case to discuss.
I think whats the correct way might be: for a field that is an array, if there is no default provided restli provides no value with this field (This statement matches the example I pasted in design doc)
If there is default for an array field, I will just use the default.
I think now the question is, is it just default provided on the schema or the element record all other default values?
Let me know if this is wrong

nodes.bodyText:
You should follow the same behavior as complex fields.

if field is not null, fill it with defaults from item's schema recursively.
if field is null and schema provides default, use the default and fill it with defaults from the item's schema recursively.
if field is null and not default provided, do nothin.

+  midLevelRecordWithoutDefault: MidLevelRecordWithDefault,

+  midLevelField: optional MidLevelRecordWithDefault
+}

+   */
+  public static DataMap fillInDefaultValues(DataSchema dataSchema, DataMap dataMap)
+  {
+    DataMap dataDefaultFilled;
+    if (dataMap != null)
+    {
+      dataDefaultFilled = new DataMap(DataMapBuilder.getOptimumHashMapCapacityFromSize(dataMap.size()));
+      dataDefaultFilled.putAll(dataMap);
+    }
+    else
+    {
+      dataDefaultFilled = new DataMap();

done

did you look at any other possible position where this can be inserted instead of response builders? and if not how did we ensure all cases are(will remain) covered where the response is being sent out

The way I find the response builder is by looking up all classes that implements the interface RestLiResponseBuilder so there are only 10 classes, I only need to implement this default filling feature in classes : ActionResponseBuilder BatchFinderResponseBuilder BatchGetResponseBuilder GetResponseBuilder and CollectionResponseBuilder, it covers: Action, Get, GetAll, BatchGet, Finder, BatchFinder methods
There are other classes that implements this inferface RestLiResponseBuilder I think they don't need to have this:
BatchCreateResponseBuilder
BatchResponseBuilder for  BATCH_UPDATE, BATCH_PARTIAL_UPDATE
CreateResponseBuilder
EmptyResponseBuilder
PartialUpdateResponseBuilder
Let me know if I miss anything
switch case?
Done
this condition seems common and can be moved out of data schema switch construct
fillInDefaultOnXYZ.. can be combined into fillInDefaultValues with switch case. why do we need separate methods for each? and separate switch case constructs?

+1, it seems there is a lot of duplication.
You'd just need one fillDefaultOnData which takes dataSchema and an Object, does the branching based on schema type.
In all other methods, you just have to get the nested schema (eg, field, item or value schema) and call this method again.
if you are filling in default datamap you shouldn't need to recursively call for record again as all default would be there from schema
Well, according to Karthik's example, even there is a default for a record, we still need to figure out other field to see if there is a default. Let me know if we need a sync with Karthik
oh yeah no need thanks

this would increase the memory consumption unnecessarily can you optimize for this. why do you need this? you're anyway traversing for list of schema fields. can we not update and return the original datamap?
Do you mean update and return?
yup or just update will also be fine

I tried just update without creating new dataMap, in some cases it will return exception because the dataMap is read only.
I think in this regard we can not just assume we can update the dataMap, we have only one way to make the fill.
The exception is like the following:, it is caused by an internal field in DataMap _readOnly, which in the function we can not change it.

Ah! you may use DataComplex.clone() for shallow copy instead of manual deep copy.

eg, basic_case.json, array_map.json
initialize size
Updated

We should use CheckedUtil::*withoutChecking methods.
By default DataMap and DataList check for cycles when a new object is added. However, since we are controling the logic and are not creating cycles, we can skip those checks for performance.
Sure
use CheckedUtil::*withoutChecking methods.
use CheckedUtil::*withoutChecking methods.

use CheckedUtil::*withoutChecking methods.

(Similar to how you are handling lists)

Do not initialize the default map with original data. Update it as you iterate the data to fill defaults, use putWithoutchecking
